question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the generated code is executable for demonstration. Please design a word memorization system (similar to the Dingxiao Word Memorization System) using the vocabulary from the People's Education Press high school English curriculum, with adjustable daily learning quantities. The memorization system should first display English words and their Chinese meanings, then have students choose the correct Chinese meaning for given English words, followed by showing incomplete English words for students to complete, and finally presenting misspelled words again for correction. This pattern should repeat over subsequent days until all high school English vocabulary has been memorized. Please generate this word memorization system immediately.

checklist.title: Is the word database comprehensive and properly structured?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code implements a complete database of PEP high school English vocabulary with proper data structure (words, definitions, example sentences, difficulty levels, etc.). Check if the vocabulary is organized by units/lessons and if metadata includes part of speech and phonetic symbols. Score 0 if only placeholder words are used, 5 if basic word structure is implemented but incomplete, and 10 if a comprehensive dictionary with proper organization is included.

checklist.title: Is the spaced repetition algorithm properly implemented?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes a scientifically-based spaced repetition system (SRS) that schedules word reviews at optimal intervals. The algorithm should track user performance and adjust review frequency accordingly (similar to SM-2 algorithm or Leitner system). Deduct 5 points if words appear in fixed intervals regardless of mastery level, and 3 points if there's no decay factor for long-term memory. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Are all required memorization modes implemented?
checklist.description: Verify that all specified learning modes are implemented: (1) word+meaning display, (2) meaning recognition quiz, (3) word completion exercise, (4) misspelling correction. Each mode should have proper input validation and scoring. Score 0 if less than two modes are implemented, 5 if basic modes exist but are incomplete, and 10 if all required modes work as specified with proper transitions between them.

checklist.title: Is the learning progress tracking system complete?
checklist.description: Evaluate if the system properly tracks user progress including: daily learning statistics, mastery level per word, cumulative progress through the curriculum, and history of performance. The system should provide persistence (local storage or server-side) to maintain progress between sessions. Deduct 5 points if progress isn't saved between sessions, and 3 points if statistics aren't granular enough for meaningful feedback. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as invalid user inputs, unexpected data formats, browser compatibility issues, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should handle edge cases like empty word lists or interrupted sessions. Give 10 points for comprehensive error handling, 5 points for basic validation, and 0 points if errors cause system crashes.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the learning experience (e.g., 1. Audio pronunciation of words 2. Visual mnemonics for difficult words 3. Gamification elements like streaks/achievements 4. Word etymology information). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple progress tracking systems) 2. Function modules unrelated to vocabulary memorization (e.g., a built-in calculator) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., unnecessary animations during word display). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating data/business logic/view layers), code reusability, and maintainability. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if there's no clear organization of vocabulary data management. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional font system (body font size ≥ 14px, line height over 1.5 times). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic text-image layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Quiz feedback delay ≤ 100ms 2) Transition between learning modes is smooth (300-500ms) 3) Clear visual guidance during different learning phases. Deduct 5 points for each operation without feedback, 3 points for jarring transitions between learning modes, and 5 points for unintuitive word completion interfaces. The full score is 10 points.
